"October 5, 2015 Vaccinations for flu and pneumonia at dr. office, both injections in left arm. October 6, 2015 Can not move left arm, very painful, can barely walk, left leg does not seem to work well, almost fell on way to bathroom. Felt as if I has no control of the movements of the left side of my body. No change for 7 days as I spent all the time in a recliner. October 14, 2015 Can now lift my left arm approximately 6 inches, left leg is beginning to work but does not synchronize with my right leg while trying to walk. Soles of feet have stinging sensations constantly and skin feels as if it is being poked with needles. My right side is starting to respond similarly to my left side. My arms feel as if they are asleep for a couple hours at a time. Sometimes hands and feet will tingle for an hour or so. I have no sensation in my fingertips, I can not feel things. My fingernails have broken to the quick and are not growing. October 30, 2015 I can lift my arms high enough to put on shirts, but is very painful. My left arm hurts constantly. Nov. 11, 2015 My legs seem to work together  a little better. There have been two instances when everything seemed to be working fairly well and without ant warning both legs just seemed almost paralyzed. One time I was at market and did not think I could get to my car in the parking lot. This frightened me so much that I now carry a folding cane at all times. Nov. 16, 2015 I had a dr. appointment today. The dr. had an intern student on staff that day. She was sent in to see me. I was in terrible condition and I told her about all of my symptoms. She talked with me for about 30 minutes. She recorded all of the information into the computer. The dr. entered the room and stated that this was going to be a short visit- Do you need any medication refills? He did not examine me, I question his examination report for that day. Nov. 22, 2015 I am now having bladder problems. I can not keep my urine stream going. It is difficult to start urinating, and then the flow stops, sometimes I start and stop urinating 9-10 times before I can empty my bladder. This occurs event if  my bladder seems very full. I have never had this problem previously and I have not had any medication changes. It is a struggle to ensure that I get my bladder empty. Today I went to the bathroom, when I pulled down my pants I was surprised to discover that I had soiled my pants. It was very runny, I had not passed gas, I did not know it had happened. Now I fear it will happen when  I am not home. Dec. 6, 2015 I think I have a bladder infection, but a trip to the dr. and a urine test does not indicate an infection. Even though I have had muscular pain for a few years, all of the new pains are completely different. I hope these new pains recede soon as I just seem to be getting weak and do not seem to be seeing any improvement. I have started physical therapy, trying to improve my legs. Jan. 6, 2016 I had an MRI today, to check for any physical reason that my bladder does not work correctly. Nothing was identified on the MRI."

"Case number PHHY2016US006986, is an initial spontaneous report received from the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS reference number: 605762) website on 18 Jan 2015. This report refers to a 57 years old male patient. Past medical history and concomitant medication were not reported. The patient was vaccinated with FLUVIRIN (batch number: 173989) intramuscularly into left arm on 21 Oct 2015. On the same day after vaccination, patient experienced congestion, diaphoresis, flushing, tongue tingling, joint discomfort, dyspnea. The outcome of the events was reported as complete recovery on an unknown date. The seriousness of the events was reported as non serious and causality was not reported. Seriousness assessment of respiratory tract congestion, flushing, paraesthesia oral and dyspnoea were upgraded based on information available in source document. Quality assurance (QA) department confirmed that, the reported batch number 173989 is not valid batch number for FLUVIRIN. Hence, investigation could not be performed. Follow up information received from Quality assurance (QA) department on 29 Jan 2016: Added QA comment."

"Based upon the follow-up information received on 27-Jan-2016, influenza vaccine was added as a company suspect drug. Initial information regarding this clinically sponsored solicited case was received on 13-Jan-2016 from the patient via the Patient Support Program. This case concerns an approximately 64 year old adult male patient who had mild flu symptoms few days after and was feeling tired and felt funny, unspecified time after receiving Praluent and influenza vaccine. No past drugs or concurrent conditions were reported. On 30-Dec-2015, the patient commenced therapy with subcutaneous alirocumab injection at the dose of 75 mg every other week (lot/batch number and expiry date unspecified) for Hyperlipidemia, unspecified delivered via alirocumab prefilled pen. On an unknown date, the patient started treatment with influenza vaccine (dose, form, route, frequency, lot/batch number and expiry date: unknown). On an unknown date, the patient reported having mild flu symptoms that started a few days after last injection. An unspecified time later, since an unknown date, the patient has been feeling tired lately. Reportedly, today was the first day he was starting to feel a little bit better. He has had sinus trouble for over 20 years and it was not unusual for him to have flu symptoms. Upon follow-up it was reported the patient felt funny after the 1st injection. He did develop flu-like symptoms. Symptoms were not severe. Patient not sure if it was the alirocumab or the flu shot that he received 2 weeks before. No information on any corrective treatment received was provided, and alirocumab was continued as planned. At time of reporting, the outcome of was unknown for feeling abnormal and recovering for other events. Reporter causality: Unknown for alirocumab and not reported for influenza vaccine. Company causality: Not associated for alirocumab and associated for influenza vaccine. Additional information was received on 27-Jan-2016 from the patient via patient support program: Influenza vaccine was added as a company suspect drug, new event of feeling abnormal was added and narrative was amended."

After initial reaction was controlled treatment continued with oral steroids and oral Benadryl for a course of 7 days. Joint aches and weakness were present for 2 weeks after vaccination and numbness of arm and hand on the side of the vaccination. GI upset including diarrhea was experienced as well. A fever of 101.2 was noted the night of vaccination and continued off and on for 3 days. 15 days after vaccination, labs drawn by Primary MD showed a TSH of 26, Thyroid panel was normal in Sept of 2015 and no changes had been made to medication prior to the vaccine. Thyroid continues to be unregulated at this time."
"Pain in rt. shoulder, deltoid and bicep. Treating with heat, cream. Little relief."
"Based on additional information received on 28 January 2016, this case got medically confirmed and also initially this case considered as non-serious was upgraded to serious due to important medical events vaccination site cellulitis and swelling arm. Initial unsolicited report received from a consumer on 12 November 2015. This case involves a 78-year-old female patient who was vaccinated with a dose of Fluzone HD (batch number was not reported) intramuscularly on left deltoid and also received a dose of Pneumonia vaccine (batch number, route and site of administration were not reported) on 10 November 2015. The patient's medical history includes seasonal allergies, illness at time of vaccination was reported as none and birth defects, medical conditions were not reported. The patient's concomitant medications were not reported. On 11 November 2015, one day following the vaccination, the patient had experienced swelling in both upper arms but the left deltoid was swollen worsened than the right deltoid, redness, burning sensation and it was hot to touch. The patient had also experienced pain from the deltoid area down the arm to the wrist. The patient felt dizzy and was having bouts of diarrhea. The patient required ER/doctor visit. Laboratory data was not reported. The patient had received Levaquin (once a daily) for one week as corrective treatment. The patient was not recovered from the events. List of documents held by sender: none. Follow up information received from a health care professional on 28 January 2016. It was reported that the patient did not receive any vaccination on 20 January 2016, and stated that patient came to office after receiving both vaccines on 10 November 2015 and it was noted that patient had cellulitis to both injection sites. Patient was treated with depo Medrol 80mg which was given intramuscularly. Patient returned to follow-up on 14 November 2015, and Levaquin was continued for one week. List of documents held by sender: none. Sender's Comments: Vaccination site cellulitis is unexpected after INFLUENZA USP TRIVAL A-B HIGH DOSE SUBVIRION VACCINE and PNEUMOCOCCAL VACCINE. Time to onset is compatible with a role of both of the vaccines. Additional information on the complementary investigation results confirming the diagnosis of cellulitis, cleansing of the vaccine injection site, patient medical history (trauma, insect/animal bite, pathologies increasing the risk of cellulitis), as well as identification of the pathogen responsible for the event is needed to further assess this case."
"Upon second medical examination of the case during internal review, a significant correction was performed on 5 February 2016 to correct the product code from INFLUENZA VACCINE to INFLUENZA USP TRIVAL A-B HIGH DOSE SUBVIRION VACCINE. Initial unsolicited report received from a pharmacist on 17-Nov-2015. This case involves a 75-year-old female patient, who was vaccinated with first dose of 0.5 ml PREVNAR (manufacturer: Wyeth, Batch number: M06899 expiry date: Mar-2017) and first dose of Flu shot (manufacturer: Unknown, Batch number: UI491AA) both via intramuscular route in left arm on 11-Nov-2015 at 14:30. Patient had no illness at the time of vaccination. Patient denied other medications and other medical conditions. Concomitant medication was not reported. It was reported that patient had no adverse event following prior vaccination. On 11-Nov-2015, same day within five minutes after vaccination, patient developed a bump at the PREVNAR injection site which was about the size of a quarter in diameter, rose up to about 1/2 in height and stopped. Patient had also received flu shot an inch away from the PREVNAR injection site and the patient had no reaction to the flu shot injection. Laboratory investigation and corrective treatment was not reported. At the time of this report patient was recovering from the event. Documents held by sender: none. Addendum on 5-Feb-2016: Upon second medical examination of the case during internal review, a significant correction was performed on 5 February 2016 to correct the product code from 'INFLUENZA VACCINE' to 'INFLUENZA USP TRIVAL A-B HIGH DOSE SUBVIRION VACCINE'."

"This spontaneous case was initially received on 26-Oct-2015. The case report was received from a(n) Non Health Professional and concerns a(n) 60 years old female patient. Weight: not provided, Height: 63.5 inches. For concomitant medication and therapy dates refer to the appropriate report sections. Suspect drug(s), timing and conditions surrounding the onset of reaction(s)/event(s): The patient received Afluria for indication Protection against the influenza virus on 20-Oct-2015 - 20-Oct-2015, Batch no: not provided, Route of administration: Intramuscular, Dose: no information provided. Additional suspect drug(s): No additional drugs suspected. Reaction(s)/event(s) and outcome: On 22-Oct-2015, after starting / treatment with Afluria the patient experienced Drowsiness (non serious, outcome: Not Recovered / Not Resolved), Malaise/Increased malaise (non serious, outcome: Not Recovered / Not Resolved), Chills (non serious, outcome: Not Recovered / Not Resolved), Felt warm/[Had a fever because] she was warm to touch/Feeling hot/Forehead was hot to touch (non serious, outcome: Not Recovered / Not Resolved). On 25-Oct-2015, after starting / treatment with Afluria the patient experienced Fever (non serious, outcome: Not Recovered / Not Resolved), Nasal congestion/Congestion in context of nasal congestion (non serious, outcome: Not Recovered / Not Resolved). On an unknown date, after starting / treatment with Afluria the patient experienced Rhinorrhoea (non serious, outcome: Not Recovered / Not Resolved). Action taken: discontinued. Event treatment: No antipyretic treatment. Patient treated with oxymetazoline. For relevant test results see appropriate report section. Reporter's assessment: ***Follow-up information received from a HCP on 06-Nov-2015: The reporter reported the term 'lack of effect' and assessed the causality as 'unlikely' in relation to Afluria. ***Case correction 08-Feb-2016: AE 8 'lack of effect' updated to core listed, AEs 1 to 8 upgraded to serious based on reported lack of effect. Sender's Comments: Company's evaluation and comment: Seriousness criterion/criteria: Non serious. Listedness: According to the Reference Safety Information, the events Malaise/Increased malaise, Chills and Fever are listed events of Afluria, the events Drowsiness, Felt warm/[Had a fever because] she was warm to touch/Feeling hot/Forehead was hot to touch, Nasal congestion/Congestion in context of nasal congestion and Rhinorrhoea are unlisted events of Afluria. Case Causality: Possible. Company's evaluation and comment 26-Nov-2015: no change in assessment. Company evaluation and comment: updated 11-Feb-2016. Seriousness criterion/criteria: Medically significant due Lack of effect. Listedness: Assessment according to the CCDS for CSL Inactivated Influenza Virus Vaccine, and the Afluria PI, drowsiness is unlisted. All other events (malaise, increased malaise and chills, warm to touch, feeling hot, forehead hot to touch, nasal congestion, congestion  and rhinorrhoea) are listed in context of Influenza like illness (ILI). Lack of effect is also listed as vaccine efficacy is not 100%. Causality: Possible. Time to onset is 3 days for initial events(drowsiness, malaise, chills, fever) and 6 days for respiratory tract symptoms. The time to onset is not consistent for lack of efficacy as seroconversion following immunisation takes at least 2 weeks. Additionally there is no lab data to suggest Influenza infection. The events most likely represent Influenza like illness which is defined as fever, in association with  upper respiratory tract symptoms (nasal congestion and rhinorrhoea) and 2 systemic symptoms (chills malaise). ILI can occur in the week following vaccination. Causality is considered possibly related for all events but not in context of vaccination failure. Causality is unrelated for event of Lack of effect."

"9/24/15: flu shot administered in the morning.  Stabbing, shooting extreme pain felt deep within my shoulder immediately at time of injection that traveled down my arm into my fingertips which tingled.  My fiance was in the office with me and he saw my reaction to this injection.  I have had flu shots before and while they are not pleasant I have never felt this type of pain with any past injection before. The arm pain continued to get worse.  I used heat thinking it was some sort of muscle soreness and I gave it some time to be sure it wasn't just the soreness associated with the injection site but this was deep within the shoulder, not like past injections where the injection site would be sore. 10/4/15: Notified my Doctor.  Advised to ice the area off and on and to let my Doctor know how it feels after 2 weeks. After the 2 weeks no improvement called my Doctor back.  Advised to do another round of ice for another 2 weeks.  Still no improvement advised to come into the office. 11/2/15: appt with Dr.  She checked it out and prescribed Diclofenac Sod Dr 75mg Tab.  Took as prescribed.  Some improvement while on this medication but soon after I had completed taking all medication the pain came back.  Notified Dr of this. 11/23/16: another round of Diclofenac Sod Dr 75mg Tab.  Same as before- some improvement while taking medication but soon after completing pain came back.  Notified Doctor of this-referred to Shoulder Specialist. 1/4/16: appt with shoulder specialist.  X Rays were taken and cortisone shot adminstered.  Immediate relief from the shot for 2 weeks.  On the 3rd week the pain came back. 1/25/16: follow up visit with shoulder specialist.  At the time of the follow up appt, pain was back.  I am getting married on 2/17/16 so at the time of this appt shoulder specialist said he did not want me to do anything until after the ceremony.  Prescribed Methylprednisolone 4mg DosePak to take if needed at time of wedding ceremony.  Shoulder specialist wants to see me soon after marriage and has mentioned Physical Therapy for future treatment.  Right now TBD."

"This case was reported by a consumer via call center representative and described the occurrence of iron decreased in a 16-year-old male patient who received FLUARIX. Previously experienced adverse reactions included tremor, nausea, anxiety, numbness and tingling (after receiving FLUARIX vaccine in Oct 2014, refers case US2016018245). Previously administered products included Flu vaccine (non-GSK vaccine received prior to 2014 without experiencing any adverse events). Concurrent medical conditions included esophageal acid reflux and pineal gland cyst (since birth). Concomitant products included MENINGITIS VACCINE, omeprazole and vitamin D nos. In October 2015, the patient received FLUARIX (intramuscular). In November 2015, 30 days after receiving FLUARIX, the patient experienced nausea, anxiety, numbness of extremities, tingling feet/hands and panic attack. On an unknown date, the patient experienced iron decreased. The patient was treated with iron. In December 2015, the outcome of the nausea, anxiety, numbness of extremities, tingling feet/hands and panic attack were recovered/resolved. On an unknown date, the outcome of the iron decreased was not recovered/not resolved. It was unknown if the reporter considered the iron decreased, nausea, anxiety, numbness of extremities, tingling feet/hands and panic attack were recovered/resolved. On an unknown date, the outcome of the iron decreased was not recovered/not resolved. It was unknown if the reporter considered the iron decreased, nausea, anxiety, numbness of extremities, tingling feet/hands and panic attack to be related to FLUARIX. Additional details were provided as follows: This case was previously reported to a doctor. This case was reported by the patient's grandmother. In 2015, the patient also had  meningitis vaccine along with flu vaccine, but the reporter thought the patient only had flu vaccine in 2014. The reporter did not know which GLAXOSMITHKLINE flu vaccine the patient received. In November 2015, approximately 1 month after receiving the vaccine, the patient experienced nausea, anxiety, numbness and tingling in hands and feet, and panic attack (same symptoms occurred after vaccinated in October 2014 except the tremors). The patient had a total of 2 panic attacks that required a visit to the emergency room (ER) between November 2015 and December 2015. The patient sometimes had more minor symptoms that subsided without medical attention. This year the symptoms were more concentrated on the patient's right side. In 2015, the patient underwent laboratory test such as Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI), Electroencephalogram (EEG) and Computerized tomogram (CT), but all that was found was a cyst on the patient's pineal gland that was thought to be benign and something he was born with. Since December 2015, the patient did not experience any event. At the time of reporting, the patient had started having low iron levels."

This case involves a 66-year-old female patient who was vaccinated with a dose of Fluzone HD (batch number: UI458AA, expiration date: 24 April 2016, dose, dose number and route were not reported) in left arm on 16 October 2015. The patient's medical history includes allergy of spinach, kale and marijuana and the patient had previously received vaccination with Fluzone HD which was well tolerated. Patient's concomitant medication was not reported. On 16 October 2015 same day following the vaccination, the patient experienced reddened, hot to touch, area with burning sensation extended to below her elbow of her left arm. Then the red, hot to touch, burning sensation extended to below her elbow to wrist and her elbow was very swollen and skin felt hard. Then over next few days her right arm also became red, hot to touch, swollen, and same burning sensation from her upper arm to her wrist. The patient required ER/doctor visit. Laboratory investigations were not reported. The patient received Benadryl as a corrective treatment. The outcome of the events were not recovered. Patient's arms were much less hot with burning sensation, stated """"almost back to normal"""", although skin still feels rough. As of 23 October 2015, the swelling and redness had resolved. Sore arm shoulder. Stiffness neck stiff. Unable to left arm at times.
"Rash on back of neck, legs and redness of ears little on face. Patient took BENADRYL and its reducing rash."
"Needle injury. My husband and I went together to get our annual Flu shots. We noticed the pharmacist seemed clumsy while getting out supplies, but didn't know there could be a serious problem since we had never had problems with a vaccine before. The pharmacist gave me a shot first. It felt like he had done it too hard. Then he gave my husband a shot and blood was dripping down my husband's arm and the pharmacist was slow to do anything about it. When someone has been well trained or has lot of experience their movements are smooth and quick. They have the cotton ball ready to go and the bandaid, but he was klutzy. My arm hurt then but I thought it would go away in a couple of days. Instead it kept hurting so I took some OTC pain pills. Then I noticed that certain movements of my left arm (where the shot was given) hurt so much I stopped making those movements. Straight movements were ok but nothing to the side or back or up, as when putting my hair in a ponytail. I couldn't pick up my toddler grandkids anymore. I now wear shirts that button down the front because it hurts too much to put my arm thru a sleeve with an upwards and sideways motion. When I would roll onto my left side in bed it hurt, and I am a left-side sleeper. This keeps waking me up throughout the night. After 2 months of thinking it would get better on its own, thinking if he had hit a nerve there wouldn't be much that could be done anyway, I did some Internet research and found that it has been given a name: SIRVA. I read accounts of women who experienced what I was going through. I still gave it a few more weeks since some of the women said nothing had helped. Then with the pain still bad and certain movements very painful I went to see my primary care doctor. We ruled out a blood clot with an ultrasound, then after a second visit also did an xray of the left humerus, then an MRI of the humerus. This MRI showed degenerative changes of the shoulder so I then had an MRI of the shoulder. The MRI of the shoulder showed a partial thickness tear of the supraspinatus tendon. At time at my desk job I have pain up and down my arm, and I avoid the movements that are very painful. I take 5 ALEVE a day. If I don't take ALEVE even just holding my arm straight I can feel pain, sometimes a deep ache. I have to try to put my arm on an extra pillow in a certain way to try to get sleep. I use heat daily to help with the discomfort and have iced the upper arm/shoulder a few times also. A friend who is a physical therapist showed me 2 exercises/stretches to do telling me I couldn't stop using my shoulder completely or it would be even worse. I have now scheduled an appointment with an orthopedist. I don't know if I will eventually need surgery or not. This all started with the Flu shot. It was not the vaccine; it was his use of the needle. In one of the article I read it mentioned that most of the people this has happened to are women who are not very big. I weight 125 lbs. Articles about this state that the pain can last for months or years."
"Sore arm, within a week it hurt to extend the arm--not in shoulder joint, but upper arm, 2/22/2016, arm still hurts to move but entire upper arm turned red with several splotches.  Also had two large boils on same arm in January 2016.  Antibiotic cured one."
"Adverse effect of vaccines and biological substances, init on 2015-10-07."

"Initial unsolicited report received from a non-healthcare professional on 20-Jan-2016. This case involves a 40-year-old male patient, who was vaccinated with Fluzone (batch number: unknown, dose, dose in series, route and site of administration were not reported) on an unspecified date. Medical history and concomitant medications were not reported. On 16-Jan-2016 at 5:00 P.M, unspecified time after vaccination, patient found positive for influenza A virus test. It was reported that the patient required emergency room/doctor visit. Laboratory investigations and corrective treatments were not reported. At the time of this report patient was not recovered from the event. Documents held by sender: none. Follow up information received from the non-healthcare professional on 19 February 2016. The patient received a dose of FLUZONE (batch number U5321FA, expiration date 30 Jun 2016) on 22 October 2016. It was reported that the patient did not receive any previous vaccine. The patient did not have any known drug allergy and patient had tonsillectomy in 2001. Upon internal review this case considered as serious due to important medical events: Influenza A virus infection and vaccination failure. On 16 January 2016, two month after vaccination, the patient found positive for influenza A virus and it was a vaccination failure case. Sender's Comments: As with any vaccine, vaccination with INFLUENZA QUADRIVAL A-B VACCINE may not protect 100% of susceptible individuals. In the current case, the patient was tested positive for influenza group A 86 days post vaccination. Additional information regarding infectious work-up results, patient's immune status at the time of vaccination (medical history, concomitant medication), exact chronology with symptoms as well as confirmatory investigation results (details of test method used to confirm specific influenza A strain, e.g. PCR) are needed for complete assessment. Based on the available information, a possible vaccination failure cannot be ruled out."

"Upon internal review on 15-Jan-2016; information about suspect product has been amended. Influenza vaccine was added as an additional company suspect. Based upon the follow up information received from the patient via the patient support program on 17-Dec-2015, the reporter causality was updated from not associated to unknown and company causality was updated from associated to not associated. Based on the follow up information received on 24-Nov-2015 the reporter causality was updated from unknown to not associated and company causality was updated from not associated to associated. Initial information regarding a clinically sponsored solicited case was received on 08-Oct-2015 from a patient via a program. This case concerns an 82 years old male patient who experienced injection site bleeding, lightheaded, abdominal cramping/ stomach cramps, increased bowel movements, upset stomach and muscle pain and soreness on the same day, diarrhea after an unknown duration and face """"broke out with red spots"""" after few months of receiving treatment with PRALUENT and all unspecified time after receiving influenza vaccine. The patient had medical history of heart disease, COPD and asthma. The patient had allergy to NEOSPORIN, iodine, IVP dye and ZYCLARA. Concomitant drugs included IMDUR, PLAVIX, Aspirin and atenolol, all for heart disease. On 24-Sep-2015, the patient received his first injection with alirocumab at a dose of 75 mg every other week subcutaneously (lot/batch number: 5F005AC and expiry date unspecified) for mixed hyperlipidemia, high cholesterol, raised LDL and intermediate coronary syndrome. After first injection, patient stated that he experienced bleeding at the injection site immediately after the injection (date: 24-Sep-2015; latency: same day), lightheaded for 2-3 hours after the injection, abdominal cramping and increased bowel movements for several days after the injection. On 24-Sep-2015 (same day), the patient experienced upset stomach and had muscle pain and soreness to some extent. Upon follow up, it was stated that the patient took alirocumab 03-Dec-2015 and then had influenza vaccine (route, form, dose, frequency, strength, lot/batch number, expiration date and indication not provided). He experienced stomach cramps and on an unknown date in Dec-2015, face """"broke out with red spots"""" and diarrhea for 2 days. Previous alirocumab shot caused mild diarrhea (onset date and latency: unknown) since an unknown date in Dec-2015. Action taken: unknown for influenza vaccine and no action taken for alirocumab. It was not reported if any corrective treatment had been required. Outcome: unknown for abdominal cramping/stomach cramps and face """"broke out with red spots"""", not recovered for muscle pain and soreness and Recovered for all other events. Reporter causality: with alirocumab: not associated for lightheaded, increased bowel movements, injection site bleeding, Unknown for abdominal cramping/stomach cramps, face """"broke out with red spots"""" and diarrhea and not reported for muscle pain and soreness. With influenza vaccine: not reported. Company causality: with alirocumab: associated for injection site bleeding and not associated for all other events. With influenza vaccine: not associated. Additional information was received from the patient via the patient support program on 24-Nov-2015: Height and weight of the patient was added. Medical history, past drugs and allergy history added. Reporter causality was updated from unknown to not associated and company causality was updated from not associated to associated. Indication of alirocumab added as raised LDL. Therapy start date and event onset dates was updated from 23-Sep-2015 to 24-Sep-2015. Clinical course updated and text was updated accordingly. Additional information was received from the patient via the patient support program on 17-Dec-2015: Indications were updated. Event term was updated for abdominal cramping. New events of red blotches and diarrhea were added. Repo"""""

The patient's medical history and concomitant medications were not reported. On an unspecified date, following the vaccination, the patient had bronchial stuff and like cold in his chest. It was also reported that while receiving injection patient got a bruise about size of silver dollar when pinched the skin up but he didn't get bruise when skin didn't pinch. Sender's Comments: This is a poorly documented and non-medically confirmed case. "This case was reported by a consumer via patient support programs and described the occurrence of vaccination failure in a 78-year-old male patient who received Influenza vaccine. Co-suspect products included ADVAIR Diskus inhalation powder for asthma and emphysema. The patient's past medical history included pneumonia. Concurrent medical conditions included arthralgia multiple (airplane flying accident), emphysema (taking ADVAIR) and asthma (taking ADVAIR). Concomitant products included amlodipine, FLONASE, SINGULAIR, NAPROSYN, PROAIR HFA, Aspirin (Baby) and prednisone. In October 2015, the patient received influenza vaccine (intramuscular). In April 2001, the patient started ADVAIR Diskus (inhaled) 1 puff(s) once daily. In October 2015, an unknown time after receiving influenza vaccine and ADVAIR Diskus, the patient experienced underdose. In November 2015, the patient experienced vaccination failure (serious criteria GSK medically significant), influenza, shivering, difficulty breathing, weight loss, unable to eat, tiredness, diarrhea and vomiting. ADVAIR Diskus was continued with no change. On an unknown date, the outcome of the vaccination failure and underdose were unknown and the outcome of the influenza, shivering, difficulty breathing, weight loss, unable to eat, diarrhea and vomiting were recovered/resolved and the outcome of the tiredness was not recovered/not resolved. The reporter considered the vaccination failure, influenza, shivering, difficulty breathing, weight loss, unable to eat, tiredness, diarrhea and vomiting to be unrelated to influenza vaccine. The reporter considered the influenza, shivering, difficulty breathing, weight loss, unable to eat, tiredness, diarrhea and vomiting to be unrelated to ADVAIR Diskus. Additional details were received as follows: This case was received from the consumer via the vaccine patient assistance program (GlaxoSmithKline Access). In October 2015, the patient received Flu vaccine (unknown manufacturer). In November 2015 (approximately 30 days after vaccination) and December 2015, the patient experienced the flu, with multiple symptoms. Underdose was also reported as an event, it was not clear whether it corresponded to ADVAIR or Flu vaccine and the exact reason for underdose was also not provided. The patient planned to continue follow-up with his physician on an unknown date. The patient believed that the ADVAIR and flu shot (unknown manufacturer) had nothing to do with him experiencing the flu, including the multiple symptoms as listed above. The patient was transferred from GlaxoSmithKline Access. This case was as suspected vaccination failure since the laboratory confirmation of the flu was not available."

Laboratory investigation and corrective treatment was not reported. The outcome of event was unknown. Upon internal review, the company decided to consider the event serious because of important medical event tested positive for A and B strains of """"flu virus"""", flu like symptoms and suspected vaccination failure. List of documents held by sender: none. Sender's Comments: As with any vaccine, vaccination with influenza vaccine may not protect 100 percent of susceptible individuals. However, additional information on the patient's immune status at the time of vaccination (medical history, concomitant medication), previous vaccinations, infectious work-up results to rule out alternative etiology and details of tests used to identify the influenza strain (e.g. PCR, nasal swab, etc.) are needed to further assess this case."""""

"Continuing pain at flu injection site; decreased range of motion of left arm. Unable to lift arm, move arm to back or extend arm."
"October 8, 2015: (4:00 PM) I received the influenza vaccination at a community health (flu immunization) clinic held at High School. This one day clinic was sponsored by the County Health Department. The woman who administered my injection recommended that I get the higher dose since I was 65 years old, so I agreed to that. She said that my arm may be a little sorer than it would be with the regular injection. I have received influenza injections for many years and have never had an adverse reaction other than some tenderness at the injection site. I had never experienced any injuries to or problems with my left arm prior to this injection. October 8, 2015: (@8:00 PM) A few hours after the injection my upper arm (at the injection site) was extremely sore and raising my arm was difficult and painful. This continued for the next few days and I had to have assistance getting dressed as I could not raise my arm. I was not able to drive my car because of the arm pain and lack of mobility. After about four days these symptoms improved but certain movements of my arm continued to be painful. This pain was most noticeable at night when I would try to sleep on the affected side. November 6, 2015 Approximately a month after receiving the injection I was still experiencing arm pain so I contacted the office of my primary care physician and explained my symptoms to her nurse. The nurse advised me to take ibuprofen (which I had already been taking) and try to use my arm more to see if that would help. I followed that advice without any noticeable improvement. November 17, 2015 I had an appointment with Dr. regarding my arm/shoulder pain. I related my experience to her and she examined my arm but was uncertain as to what might be causing my pain or how to treat it. She recommended trying physical therapy and if that did not help she suggested I may want to see an orthopedic doctor and have x-rays or an MRI of my arm. November 24, 2015 I began physical therapy sessions with DPT. These sessions, along with prescribed home exercises, seemed to improve my symptoms, especially reducing the pain I experienced during the night. In mid-December of 2015 we traveled to spend the winter so I discontinued the therapy but continued the home exercises. January 8, 2016 I once again began to suffer with increased pain in my arm and shoulder, especially at night. I met with an orthopedic doctor. I had originally made the appointment to discuss problems with my arthritic knee but he also examined my left arm/shoulder. Dr. thought it was possibly an issue with my rotator cuff and believed the timing of the flu shot may be just coincidental. He gave me a cortisone injection in my shoulder and recommended returning for some type of imaging of the shoulder if the shot did not provide adequate pain relief. The shot did relieve some of the arm/shoulder pain for about a month, but then the pain gradually returned and continued to worsen. Not only was I in pain but I also started to lose mobility in my left arm and my range of motion was rapidly decreasing. I decided to return home and consult with my orthopedic physician there. March 22, 2016 I had an appointment with an orthopedic specialist. He examined me and took x-rays of my left arm and shoulder. Given the fact that my symptoms started immediately after I received the flu shot and added to the fact that I had never experienced any injuries or other issues with my left arm or shoulder, he said it was very likely that the administration of the flu vaccine could have caused my arm/shoulder issues. He thought the vaccine may have been injected too high on my arm. Upon further examination he diagnosed me with adhesive capsulitis, """"frozen shoulder"""", which he also believed could have resulted from the vaccine administration, causing the pain and subsequent mobility issues. Due to my shoulder pain and immobility he did not feel I could keep my arm in the necessary position to undergo an MRI evaluation at that time. H"""""
Hearing loss in left ear. Has gone through treatment with cortisone injections but not effective.
Immediately after administration patient had extreme pain in upper arm at the site of the injection. The pain was immediate and has lasted for months.
